title: 105_hr2408
content: The "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students by offering productive activities during after school hours. The findings in the "After School Education and Safety Act of 1997" highlight the increased social risks faced by today's youth, including spending more unsupervised time alone and being at higher risk of violence during after school hours. The goals of the Act include increasing academic success, improving students' skills, promoting safe environments, preparing for workforce participation, and providing alternatives to negative activities. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "school" as a public kindergarten, elementary, or secondary school, and "Secretary" as the Secretary of Education. SEC. 6. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to schools for carrying out activities described in section 7(a). SEC. 7. AUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES; REQUIREMENTS. Each school receiving a grant under this Act must conduct at least 2 of the following activities: mentoring programs, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training. Additionally, schools may choose to implement drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities. Each school receiving a grant under this Act may conduct drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation activities after regular school hours. Activities should reflect the specific needs of the population, students, and community served. A school receiving a grant under this Act must provide activities after regular school hours that reflect the specific needs of the population served. The activities should take place in a designated school building or public facility, and the school is encouraged to request volunteers from the business and academic sectors. A school receiving a grant under this Act must provide activities after regular school hours in a designated school building or public facility. The school is encouraged to request volunteers from the business and academic communities, donations of computer equipment, and collaborate with State and local park and recreation agencies for activities described in the Act. The school receiving a grant under this Act is encouraged to collaborate with communities for mentorship, request computer equipment donations, and coordinate with State and local park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 8. APPLICATIONS. Each school seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, detailing how the goals of the Act will be met, evidence of collaboration, administration of activities, and utilization of resources. The application for a grant must show collaborative efforts by various stakeholders, describe how activities will be administered, avoid duplication of services, outline funding sources, and include a plan for non-Federal funding. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $50,000,000 for each fiscal year from 1998 to 2002.
